novel_text:
Patrice had learned the city by the sound of its metal. Tram bells clipped the mornings like small coins tossed into a jar, guttering pipes breathed and coughed when the southerly pushed rain back into them, and the station’s tinny loudspeakers made everything into an announcement even when there was nothing to declare. He would wake early, before the first shift of sun found the couch he slept on, and sit with his knees tucked up and his mug cradled between his palms, waiting for the first sound to decide him. The bell, the pipes, the speaker. Some days it took all three.

The unit he rented sat behind a sagging terrace in Fitzroy with flaking paint the colour of chalk. A narrow passageway led to a backyard of pavers and old pots, and up above that backyard was another unit with a small balcony that looked like it would fold under the weight of a heavy bird. On the balcony, sometimes, there was a blue towel that turned grey when it rained and a string of battered prayer flags that might have been bought at a market. Sometimes there were plants in chipped teacups. Once there was a row of lemons, lined up like a parade.

The first morning he saw her she was standing barefoot on that balcony, biting into a lemon like it was an apple. He heard the soft sound she made at the sourness and then he heard himself laugh before he had time to decide if laughter was the correct response.

She looked over the railing and found him, his cup and his knees, the soft grin he could not swallow away.

“Unlucky lemon,” she said.

“Or you’re very brave,” he said back.

She tilted the lemon at him as though toasting with it. She was wearing a jumper with holes in the cuffs, and her hair was pinned with a pencil. The pencil sat there in such a natural way that he imagined she’d been born with it. The morning, too, was full of a natural kind of messy: pale light, the tight buzz of the neighbour’s aircon, a dog barking somewhere like it was working through its own thoughts.

He lifted his cup. “Patrice,” he said.

“I’m Mira,” she answered. Then her face opened a notch. “Patrice like—French Patrice? Or like… is there another Patrice?”

“My dad’s family came from Mauritius, if that counts,” he said. “Mum comes from Bendigo and a line of people who say they came from nowhere in particular.”

“Somewhere in between, then,” she said. “That’s my favourite part.”

She bit the lemon again. He watched her eyes water and he laughed, and she laughed too, and the city put its coin-bell into the jar on their behalf and everything began.

After that, mornings arrived a bit softer. There was a new box of small sounds in them: the scrape of her balcony chair, the whispered swear of a pot falling and soil rolling across the boards, the murmur of a radio playing something that was all violin and rain. He learned she wore the pencil on Mondays, she watered the teacup plants in the evening with a jug, she lifted the blue towel and folded it carefully like it was a letter. He learned the way she said “morning” from her throat like a secret, and later, the way she said his name with a friendly question mark that she forgot to remove.

Patrice loved noticing. He’d never been paid for it before. At Flinders Street he worked in Lost Property, which meant he lived in the aftermath of everyone else’s forgetting. They brought in the bags, and the hats, and the phones that had been less necessary at the critical moment than the exit sign. They brought in a violin case with nothing inside it but dust and a photograph of two boys on a pier. There was a shoe with a jewelled buckle; there was a shoe without a jewelled buckle. There were umbrellas that had chosen better weathers. And the hands that passed him these things were hurried, apologetic hands—like they had offended the objects somehow.

He hadn’t planned to work among ghosts. He’d wanted, for a period of two years, to fix clocks. He had known despite not knowing how that would happen that his hands loved the idea of small screws, gears shining with a kind of oil that always smelled faintly like lemon. But there had been other loves he was not certain he could survive if he named them. There had been his mother’s heart, which worked on its own time zones. There was the rent. There was the fact that fixing clocks felt like an act of violence against the concept of freedom come to think of it. So he had taken the job behind the little window where glass made everyone into museum exhibits and watched the whole city remember and forget and remember again.

“Do you judge what comes in?” Mira asked from the balcony one Saturday, leaning on the railing like it was an old friend. “Does a violin mean a different person than, say, a lunchbox with a cartoon dinosaur?”

“Less strawberry jam in the violin,” he said. “More weeping when they realise.”

“So you do judge,” she said, smiling. She had a way of pushing at him gently, as if she were trying to find his edges but didn’t mind if they shifted.

He shrugged. “I like the lost things that come in with stories attached. There was a wallet with a list in the coin pocket and the list said: buy milk, call Auntie Moira, forgive yourself. The man who came back for it said me keeping it safe had saved his week. I liked that.”

“And the dinosaur lunchbox?”

“Contained a dinosaur. Plastic. Three legs.”

“Maybe the fourth was in Lost Lunchboxes in some other city,” she said. “Everything wants to be whole.”

He looked up in a reflex to find her eyes then looked down again with an almost painful care, afraid he might have put too much in his gaze. He sipped his tea. He tried not to feel the way the words went through him like a kind of weather. Everything wants to be whole. He had not wanted to be a person who wanted like that. Or if he had, he’d wanted it politely.

“Do you work Saturdays?” he asked to move the air in a different direction.

“If I’m on a deadline,” she said. “I write. Or try to. Or write around the thing I’m supposed to be writing. Write ABOUT writing. More honest.”

“What do you write?” he asked. This came out too quick and he hated his hunger for answers. He wanted to be him, but at half pressure.

“Architecture,” she said. “And how people live in it. Columns, sometimes. Little essays for magazines no one reads on purpose. Box of words and I shake it until it makes a plan.”

“I like that,” he said, and then felt the words too simple. He added, “I like plans that happen by accident,” and that was a little closer to what he meant. He meant: I like that you speak like houses are stories and people are furniture they rearrange themselves into and out of.

She smiled, and her pencil slipped and tumbled down, landing with soft surrender on the pavers. He picked it up and held it up at arm’s length.

“Delivery,” he said.

“I’ll come down,” she said, and he felt his pulse do the little rabbit thing it hadn’t done since he was nineteen and someone had kissed him in the back room of a Brunswick pub because he’d made the right joke at the right time.

By the time she arrived at the door he had the pencil and also a sudden fear that his unit was too much him. His couch with the worn patch like a small continent. His carton of milk with a date that had passed. His books in precarious, leaning stacks: books about time, books by people who were dead and sensible, books with foxed pages and notes in the margin that said things like yes! and Sure but no. He put the pencil in her hand and the hand felt delicately cold, although the day was warm; he wanted to wrap both of his around it and send heat like a kindness.

“Thanks,” she said. She was close enough that he could see a faint smudge of soil on her cheek and a tiny scar in the shape of a comma on her collarbone. “I think better with this exact pencil. It’s like a superstition. I’ve tried to stop. I’ve failed.”

“Keep failing,” he said, and it sounded dangerously like admiration. “Do you want tea?”

“Yes, if it’s no trouble. If it is trouble, I can pretend I said no tea and then everything is consistent.”

“It’s always trouble,” he said, “and you’re welcome.”

They sat at the little table near the window where light fell in a net through the backyard grapevine. He had bought the table second-hand, and there was a burn in the shape of an island in the middle of it. Mira put her fingertips against the burn as though reading it like Braille.

“My grandmother used to tell me,” he said impulsively, “that every mark a house gets is a kind of map. That’s how you know people were alive there.”

“She sounds like the kind of woman who would lift a carpet when she moved in, just to see if there were old squares of sun,” Mira said.

“She would have, if she’d had a carpet. She had lino and pride.”

“What about you?” she asked. “Maps?”

“I have one in my head,” he said. “Of the station. It’s ridiculous. A map of lost property. Red umbrella—row one. Violins and odd musical objects—cracked shelf under the window. Wallets without ID—a shoebox with a lid that says LID. The handwriting’s mine, the joke isn’t.”

“Oh,” she said in a tiny voice that felt like a yes. “You must be good at holding strangers’ stories without dropping them.”

“Sometimes I add them to my own to keep them warmer,” he said, and then the kettle rattled in a way that made him jump and think of earthquakes and he went to pour the tea.

When he came back she was reading the spines of his books. “Austerlitz,” she said, mispronouncing it so that it became a bright and jubilant place rather than a man walking through dim rooms with his ghosts. “I read this when I was nineteen and thought it was about trains and then realised it was about leaving.”

“It’s about both,” he said. “And about how the city remembers for you when you can’t.”

She smiled, that slow light without heat. “You talk about the city like it’s a person.” She paused. “I do that too.”

They drank tea and talked about ridiculous things: whether magpies had accents in different suburbs, whether lost property boxes counted as tiny museums, whether it was possible to grow a tomato plant in a teacup with a string to the drainpipe and a prayer. He felt that particular lightness that came when you were allowed to be foolish without being corrected. He thought he had missed that more than any one person. There were spiky bits in him that smoothed. There were sharp bits he didn’t mind.

For a while, a long while like a secret pocket sewn into time, that was enough. Mornings with her lemon and pencil. Evenings with her tea as the sky bruised itself. Sundays with the smell of roast lamb drifting from the terrace kitchen because the owner upstairs was Greek and he was always cooking like a demonstration that joy could be exertion. She knocked sometimes to borrow a pan. He knocked sometimes to borrow the quiet when his radio refused to work and the footy fans in the next terrace were braying like injured cattle. It was neighbourly and then it wasn’t, quite. He began to watch the way she moved in the world like it had agreed to an arrangement with her. He began to listen for her cough and invent elaborate stories about why she coughed. He wrote a note to himself in the margin of a paperback: do not fall in love at the same pace as water evaporates, you will not notice until you are thirsty.

He kept noticing. He failed to stop. He succeeded to fail.

One late afternoon, he found her in the hallway with her arms full of flowers. Dried, mostly. Banksia and paper daisies. There was a frame under one arm and in the other hand she was balancing a cake tin that looked, incongruously, like something a grandmother with hard ankles would carry to Church. She looked flushed, pleased with herself in a gentle, disbelieving way.

“Is there a festival you forgot to invite me to?” he said, stepping to one side to let her pass. His heart hurt at the thought that there might be a world she’d go to in which he was not yet—invited.

“Exhibition,” she said. “Well, a room in an exhibition. I wrote a piece about a defunct public housing block and old women who embroidered over their utility bills and somehow it touched a nerve somewhere. I get a corner and a plinth, like a small island.”

“That’s—” he searched for a word that contained the right weight. “Right.”

She grinned. “You’ll come?”

“To the small island? I’d swim for it.”

She leaned into the door with her shoulder and almost dropped the cake tin. He grabbed it without thinking and felt a range of lives settle into his hands: scones, slices, brownies. Lemon, if there was justice.

“I made a cake,” she said sheepishly, “for the people who made the rest of the exhibition actually happen. I’ve never met them. I thought cake was a universal language.”

“The best diplomacy is sugar,” he said. He wanted to add, Please cut two slices now, we will eat them in the hallway and you will tell me your secrets and I will tell you mine. He said nothing like that.

She had to go, to deliver flowers and frame and cake and herself to the island. She left a small parabola of air that smelled like eucalyptus soap and the faintest breath of lipstick. He knew the exhibition was in Southbank. He knew this because he had seen a flyer and pretended not to know when she told him, because it seemed less needy not to.

When he closed his door he felt a glass pane slide into place between him and the world. It wasn’t unpleasant. The week glided. He kept his head down at the window at the station and put umbrellas in their place, and the bins that took bent things like the bent things might be less upset if they were together, and read the names on luggage tags like poems. There was always someone, somewhere, who had forgotten a hat that made no sense. There was a hat shaped like a cake. There was a hat shaped like a ship. There was a hat shaped like a hat, which somehow felt surprising after the ship. When a man came for the hat that was a hat he said his name and the name was Julian Selkirk and it sat on Patrice’s tongue like a thin coin. Men like that always said their names like you should have already known. They had sharp shoes and no fear of glass.

“Ah,” Julian said, when Patrice produced the hat, “there you are. My head has been cold with symbolism.”

“Lucky we keep symbols warm,” Patrice said.

“Do you?” Julian said, amused in the way that meant he was already bored. He checked himself in the reflection in the glass. “I’ll be at the Arcadia on Friday,” he added to the reflection, this time not to Patrice at all. “Everyone will. The gallery’s new show. Lots of steel and grief.”

“Enjoy it,” Patrice said, which is what you say to a person leaving your life two seconds after arriving. His fingers brushed a tag that had fallen out of the hat: a white card with a thick black stripe. On the back, in pencil, were the words: A.S.

He put the card in the little tray under the glass. The city said its usual things: Train delayed, Service resumed, Mind the gap between yourself and yourself.

That night, on her balcony, Mira had music turned up louder than usual, an old record with crackling like a fire. He could hear people too, voices he didn’t know. A laugh with edges to it. A woman’s voice with a polish to it so delicate it made his teeth ache. He took his tea outside and sat on the paver nearest to the grapevine and pretended he was a bush or a planter. The voices moved like a school of fish, up and down. He could make out words: “curator,” “endowment,” “don’t mention funding to the press,” “amazing in the Times,” and then Mira said something and they all expressed the agreeable noise people make when a room decides to like someone.

He told himself this was good. He told himself he wanted her to be liked. He told himself that she could have both: the lemon on the balcony, and also kisses from women with delicate polish. He told himself so many things that the tea went cold.

Then she leaned over the railing, a little bit, and waved a quiet wave to him—just two fingers, a private semaphore. Her mouth, in a small O. So you’re there. He felt relief like someone had returned a wallet with a map in it. He lifted his cup. His smile did something unwise and tugged too much at one side of his face.

“Patrice,” she called, and the voices made room for his name. “This is—this is Selkirk,” she said, gesturing behind her. “This is Annabel—this is Duane—this is Anna, who made the thing—this is—” she ran out of names. “These are the people who make small islands into countries.”

He stood up, the old paver doing a wobble under his feet, and he thought of his shoes suddenly. They were fine shoes but they had a story: op-shop, ten dollars, some tenacious polish. He wondered if the laugh with the edges belonged to Selkirk. He wondered if that was the hat. He stood and lifted his hand and said hello and nobody answered because the record crackled at the wrong moment and then someone did, belatedly, and someone else took a tray from Mira without looking at him, and the moment slid. It didn’t feel like cruelty, it felt like weather. A small gust before the change.

He slept badly that night, by which he meant he dreamed about trains leaving and he couldn’t find the gap, or he kept finding it and stepping over and ending up where he had started. He woke with the sense that he had been told to stand in the wrong queue and obeyed, because he was obedient in ways he hated. He went to work and sorted keys. He had learned keys could be prime numbers of pain when no one came for them. A ring of keys for a person who would not return was like a little circle of unfinished sentences.

Around midday he found a small object at the back of a drawer of unsorted jewelry—cheap necklaces like the ones teens wore on the train at night, a brooch shaped like a beetle, a tangle of chain that felt almost organic. The small object was a ring. Gold, or something like it. It had that slightly warm shine of the kind of metal that has been worn by a kind hand. There was a stone, not large, a flawed oval with a sprinkle of cloud inside. Around the inside of the band there was an inscription rubbed almost to ghosting. He _knew_ he should put it in the ledger, with the time and place of discovery, and then in the tray for small valuable items that require signatures like prayers. He held it between the pads of his fingers and felt the metal give off a breath, like the metal knew him. It was probably just how skin felt when it touched something that had been warmed by another skin. It was probably nothing. But.

He put it on his smallest finger because he had to measure it. It fit. Or it didn’t. It sat there with a stubbornness, and then loosening. The room felt briefly wider and narrower at once. The loudspeaker squawked. A child cried just out of sight. A woman asked him if anyone had found a scarf with the Sydney Swans on it and he said not yet and he took the ring off carefully and placed it on the ledger and wrote: ring—gold—oval stone—inscription worn—found in Drawer B at 12:13—Flinders Street Lost. He put the time in with strictness. He had learned that being exact about some things made the sloppier parts of his nature forgive him.

He did not think of the word magic because he was not twelve. But he thought of his grandmother who had put a coin in his palm once and told him it had belonged to her mother and that if he held it the right way it would show him the last place she had been happy. He had held it and seen nothing but the ceiling with water stains and a skitter of lizard; his grandmother had said, gently, that was it, the lizard had been trusted and that was the whole story. He thought of Mira: the way her name had slipped into the party and come back out to him with its two fingers. The way she had said, you’ll come? Yes, he thought. To the island, to anything.

That evening, he went to the exhibition with the intention of being unnoticed. He wore his fine ten-dollar shoes and a shirt that still remembered an iron. He took the tram and watched three older women in soft floral dresses carrying programmes with great attention, and two young men trying not to be a couple in public like they had been told not to be. The Southbank buildings were all glass that made their insides seem too close to see. He entered and it was exactly like the party had sounded: edge-laughs and polished voices and grief in steel. He found the plinth. He found Mira’s small island: photographs of a block with its teeth knocked out, stories printed on tracing paper so that you had to layer them to read. He felt proud in a way that made him want to sit down. He wanted to touch the tracing paper with his fingertips and leave no oil.

“Mira,” he said when he found her, and she turned and there it was, that opening of her face. Relief, recognition. A little bit of joy. It was everything and not everything; he had learned to be careful with his inferences.

“You came,” she said. She had a glass of sparkling water with a slice of cucumber in it which she held like a cocktail joke. Her hair was pinned with the pencil. She had put on a dress that didn’t admit error.

“Have you seen the hat man?” he asked, because he didn’t know how to say: I am here inside of who you think I am and it feels like the right size of skin.

“Julian? He’s here somewhere. He’s always here. He keeps going to the bar and coming back with less of a drink than he left with, which is a trick. There’s Anna—there’s Duane—there’s a woman who tells me we should aim for a different kind of public housing, by which she means none.”

“And you,” he said. “You are here.” This sounded silly but necessary.

“I’m here,” she said, so gently. “Will you—stay?”

“As long as they let me,” he said, and when he said this he felt the ring in his pocket. He had put it there on a strange impulse, like a person who carries a lucky rock. Not to keep, to keep him. He knew the rules; if anyone claimed it he would be at the station with the ledger and the little tray and would say, here you go, we found a history that was warm and we warmed it a bit for you in between.

She introduced him to people. He tried to store their names with the care he stored hats; names were hats, really, that people asked you to admire. He got some right, fluffed others, found himself enjoying a joke about funding when he didn’t know the numbers, said “yes” the way the room wanted him to. He watched her move among them, and the way her attention was a gift she parceled out with fairness. Sometimes her eyes found him, like a pause to breathe. He didn’t know it then, but the pause would become a gap he had to mind.

“Do you want to meet Annabel?” she said after a while, low, as though the name were delicate.

“The delicate voice,” he said, and she smiled because he had been listening.

Annabel was polished. She had clothes that were cut in a way that made cloth behave. Her laugh did have edges, but pleasant ones—the kind that cut paper clean. The room around her did behave like a country with a strong economy. When Mira said, “Patrice works at Lost Property,” Annabel laughed in a way that seemed to check if he was joking and then accepted it wasn’t.

“Stranger things,” she said. “My sister once dated a boy who collected fridge magnets and put his favourites in a bank safety deposit box. Every time we passed the bank I felt a pull from all the tiny Islands of Must-Visit. The world’s most secure Malta.”

“Are there insecure Maltas?” he asked, and she flashed an appreciative grin that left him dazzled and uncertain of whether he had just earned points in a game he didn’t want to play.

“Annabel is,” Mira said lightly, “what is the word, a patron.”

“Oh,” Patrice said, and this was altogether too simple for what Annabel likely was. Annabel’s family probably owned parts of streets. Annabel’s father probably wrote polite letters to premiers.

“You should come up to the house,” Annabel said, like she was talking about a place in a fairy tale without knowing it. “Sunday, if you’ve no better. The garden looks like something out of an H.M. prison brochure, i.e., well-managed and a tiny bit terrifying. Mira is bringing her lemon cake, which we’ve already declared legendary.”

“I’m busy pretending to know the rules to tennis on Sundays,” Mira said, “but I could make time for a prison garden.”

Patrice felt the glass slide again. Not sharply. Not yet. He imagined a house that sat politely behind a wall; he imagined the taste of a lemon cake that had managed to leave the building before him. He imagined himself there, and then imagined himself outside the wall, and had to admit the second picture made more sense. He nodded anyway, because he was trying to live like an experiment instead of an apology.

“Thanks,” he said.

Annabel looked over his shoulder and smiled at someone whose name had a title attached to it, and excused herself in the way that made it not an apology but a fact.

“Don’t mind,” Mira said, under her breath. “She means well. She means something. I haven’t decided yet what.”

“I am an unknown quantity at the party,” he said lightly. “The variables are stacked.”

“You keep teasing,” she said, softly almost. “I like it.”

He was brave enough then to ask, “Do you know where you belong in that house?”

“No idea,” she said, and her mouth did a small shape that looked like both hope and fear. “I want to stand in the kitchen. I always want kitchens. But I suppose I should stand under the art.”

“You should stand where you can steal cake,” he said. The relief of saying something small and true made his body feel less like a costume.

He stayed until the music grew slower and the polished voices shifted from money to memory. He took the last tram home with people who were, like him, beginning to pull their night back on as if it were a damp jumper. He slept better, with a dream of paper daisies that were actually tiny suns; in the morning he liked things again. He looked up and the blue towel waved at him like a flag in the smallest country.

The week pivoted. There were more people on her balcony; there were nights when she didn’t lean over because leaning over would have felt like connecting two worlds with a bridge she wasn’t sure would bear the weight. He did not blame her. Or he blamed the feeling, ephemeral and unnameable, that rose in him like a tide when she was not there. He made his morning tea carefully. He polished the ten-dollar shoes until they looked like hope. He took the ring out of his pocket when he was alone and rolled it between his fingers. He told himself it was just a ring that had belonged to a person who would say, one day, “I lost something,” and he would say, “Here it is,” and they would say, “Thank you,” and there would be no magic required at all.

One errand-day—those days when he took the desk by himself because Kim had gone home with a migraine and the intern had wandered into an academic future—an elderly man came with a hat that was shaped like a hat and a coat that was too big for the weather. He leaned on the counter and said, “Do you have a ring,” and then stopped, either because he had lost his train or because something had come undone behind his eyes.

“What was it like?” Patrice asked gently, and the man said, “It was like a promise someone else kept,” which was not a description but then again was the only kind of description that mattered. Patrice swallowed. He showed him the small velvet tray with rings and the man shook his head, and then the man said, “I’ll come back when the ring does,” and left in a way that made the day go quiet around the edges.

That night, the wind turned and came in from the bay. The city made that humming noise a city makes when the weather changes its mind. He watched the plants on Mira’s balcony toss their opinions into the air. She appeared finally, later than she usually did, with her hair loosening and an expression he’d not seen on her, like she had tried to carry too many bags and left some on the platform. She saw him, in his small spot by the grapevine, and folded into the railing.

“Long day?” he asked.

“That house,” she said, with an exhale almost a laugh. “It’s bigger inside than outside. Good big and bad big. There was a piano in a room that no one touched, like it was a relic of a religion they didn’t practice anymore.”

“And did you stand in the kitchen?” He didn’t know why he felt like a person who had the right to ask, except she had given him that right when she talked to him like these were things that mattered.

“I stood in a hallway,” she said. “Because the hallway looked like a road. And Annabel came and stood with me and told me about a cousin who collects stamps the size of my fingernail. And then Julian came and told me my column on windows was sentimental and that was a compliment except I don’t think it was.”

“Windows deserve a little sentiment,” he said. “They do all that work letting you in and out.”

“Exactly,” she said, with the fragility of someone whose argument has been shredded and who is trying to salvage the fabric. “You get it.”

He wanted then to go up the narrow stairs and stand in the doorway of her small room and make the air between them warm with the ordinary. He wanted to hand her a pencil. He wanted to put his ringless hand against the wall and make a map. He wanted, and the wanting had edges. He saw her wanting too—maybe for rest. Maybe for lemon slices she did not have to share with a bossy hat. He saw the way her eyes moved away from him like a person reaching for their coat.

“I need—” she said, and gestured to mean sleep, and he said yes and nodded and made a little joke about the weather, and she smiled and went inside, and the bridge lifted for a ship that he could not see.

He sat with the smell of gum leaves and damp concrete and he found the ring in his pocket and put it on his smallest finger again in the dark. He did it the way you do something without asking for it to be more than it is. He felt a warmth then that might have been his blood making a neat loop. He felt, perhaps, the breath of something that was going to matter. He thought, with a stubbornness he had not known he owned: I will not be the thing that becomes invisible. And the city, obliging, placed another bell into the morning that had already begun.Morning arrived with the thin metallic ping of the tram bells and a jet weeping faintly over the suburbs, and for once he let the sound decide him without letting it decide him entirely. He was up before the couch could translate his shape back into cushions and springs, and the ring sat in his palm like an egg he was warming for a bird that had gone elsewhere. He did not put it on immediately. He made tea and burnt the first piece of toast and ran the knife back and forth over butter that was reluctant and then gave in. He carried his cup into the yard and looked up for the blue towel as though it were a flag of truce. It wasn’t there, and there was no pencil in the hair of the morning, only a row of pegs like a failed attempt at notes on a stave.

He had said a thing to himself in the dark, and the thing was tugging. He did not know how to be loud without feeling like he was taking air from others, and he did not know how to be quiet without fading to the near side of visible. The small solution he chose was to become deliberate. He washed his cup and left it upright on the rack. He folded the tea towel even though it did not need folding. He took the ring and slid it onto his smallest finger with the same care you give to a word that will change the sentence that comes after it, and he walked to work instead of catching the tram.

Walking, he noticed and re-noticed things that were too ordinary to be consolations but became consolations anyway. The milk bar on the corner with the sign that declared it sold VHS like it was a variety of ice-cream. The laneway stencils that had bloomed new birds since the last rain. The café with the chairs so light a gust could re-decorate. He reached the curve where the creek went invisible beneath the street and smelled water in stone. He wondered if he had been wrong about clocks and right about maps. The ring warmed once when he put his hand on a steel fence. It could have been the sun. It could have been something making itself known the way a dog might, nose first, gentle, interested but not yet attached.

At the station the day announced itself like a person arriving at a party determined to have a good time despite having a deep dislike of parties. The loudspeakers were in a talkative mood; the pigeons had organised themselves into a union and were striking over bread quality; the river had turned a particular Yarra-brown that meant it was thinking about its mysterious duties. He took his place behind the glass and let the city press its hands against the other side. He logged the keys with their small teeth and their secrets. He put wallets in their row like books, faces to the spines of phone numbers. He opened the drawer of umbrellas and the drawer had a presence today, like a choir in an abandoned church deciding whether to rehearse or let the acoustics sleep.

The first thing that felt like proof was a camera. Not an expensive one; one of the cheerful bricks people bought because the colour made the world seem brighter even before the photographs. A kid in a basketball singlet had left it on a bench; a Jinny or a Jaz had handed it in with a grin like they had done a small crime and enjoyed it. Patrice touched the camera and the ring pressed cool against his skin and tugged the smallest bit. Tugged was too crude a word; it insinuated. He had been ready for nothing and so anything was something. He set the camera on the counter and it felt heavier than a camera should, like it had elected to be important in a quiet way, and when a woman came not much later and asked for a camera and her voice shook like a wire in wind he was not surprised to recognise the blue rubber on the strap.

“Jasper’s,” she said, with that ridiculous relief people wear like a coat two sizes too big. “He kept photographing pigeons because he says they don’t know their own best side. He’ll be unbearable now. Thank you.”

“Pigeons do know a good side,” he said. “They just keep it for the people who notice.” He slipped the camera across and wrote the time in the ledger and his hand, without permission, added a comma after the minute mark, as if to leave room for something that fell outside ordinary measurements. The ring’s warmth pulsed once and then settled. He almost laughed, because if this was magic it had the decency to behave like good manners.

Mid-morning brought a man with a face like an unused ticket: crisp around the edges, no wear in the middle. He wore a jacket that made a sound and smelled like a certain kind of leather shop that had never once had a sale. He said he had lost a briefcase. He said this like the briefcase had stood up and walked. Patrice made the necessary inquiries and discovered the briefcase at the bottom of a stack of other people’s responsibilities. When he handed it over he saw, written in a neat pale pencil on a card in the side pocket, the two letters again: A.S. The ring grew distinctly warmer, and he made his face do that noncommittal greeting expression that meant nothing significant had entered the room. The man smiled with only half his mouth and thanked him in a way that suggested the thanks came free with the jacket.

He placed the pencil-marked card in the little tray to be filed. The ring kept being a temperature. He thought of coincidences and of how, if you let them, they built houses of superstition over your head and then moved you in and charged rent. He thought of the hat and Julian and Annabel’s name in the air like a thread that had not yet found the right hem to tug at. He took the ring off and set it on the ledger and the heat left the day like a sigh. He lifted it and put it back on. He felt obscurely ridiculous and then forgave himself. He had forgiven others for less.

When the child came he did not first see him, he heard the noise a child makes when it is trying not to be a child because children have been told to be brave and that they will receive stickers if they comply. It was a quick breath-sound and a scuff and then a silence hungry as a cupboard. He stood up and leaned out of the little window and the concourse seemed ordinary and then his eyes snagged on smallness next to a vending machine. The smallness had a Myki around its neck like an amulet and hair that looked as if a parent had done their best and then given up and declared it art. The smallness was crying without wet.

“Hey,” Patrice said, in a voice he knew to be in the right register for injured birds and lost dogs who would like to be found by a particular person and no other. “What are you looking for?”

“Mum,” the child said, and that was always the answer, and the mouth did the thing with the lip and the brave and the not quite brave. “She said—I was there—and then I wasn’t—and then—” The logic collapsed under the weight of its own premises. It happens to the best of your arguments when you are little.

“What does your mum look like?” he asked, because asking was a way of folding the child into the fabric of people. “What colour is her scarf? Does she have a laugh you can hear over trains?”

“Red scarf,” the child said, instantly, in the way kids can tell you a single true thing about a person and leave everything else to poetry. “And she has a bag with a cat on it. The cat is mad.” The tears came now that the ground felt more solid and he could afford to spend them.

Patrice had never used the loudspeaker on purpose. He had thought of the station voice as an institution, impartial, one of the gods. The gods were all a bit bored. He looked at the ring and the ring did not warm, it steadied. He pressed the button and let the system open its mouth around his small human noise and he said, very clearly, “Could the person with the red scarf and a cat on a bag please come to Lost Property. A small brave person is waiting, and the cat looks quite cross.”

He had not known, until he said it, that this was allowed. The station took the words the way a lake takes a stone. They moved and they plunked and they made circles. He saw heads turn. He saw a woman’s head whip around and then her body, and her scarf was the exact kind of red that red is when it intends to forgive you for everything even though it should not. She ran and the child ran and the reunion happened like a ceremony none of them had rehearsed and all of them had practised in their hearts. When the woman looked up at him, over the child’s hair, her gratitude was so clean it nearly scraped. “Thank you,” she said. “He likes the cat. The cat is from a book. He thinks the cat is telling him secrets.”

“They do that,” he said. “But only to people who return them to their owners.” He meant children, and cats, and rings, and cities.

After they went, he sat back down and put his hand flat on the ledger, his little finger extended along the column of times. He felt the ring’s pressure a little as though it were reminding him of itself and of the choice he had made when he pressed the button. The choice had been small and ordinary and had landed a little coin of a bell into the day. He imagined the boy as a man remembering it—the voice on a metal morning, his mother, the red scarf that looked like an exclamation Judy might wear to be friends with punctuation.

Around two, Kim arrived looking not unlike a person who had wrestled with a migraine all night and was now trying to be polite about the fact that pain held a grudge. Patrice made her tea that he suspected tasted of metal and she thanked him as though he had made it out of orchids. He told her about the cat-bag child and she smiled with one half of her face and said, “You’re a good one,” and he made a noise that could have been modesty or agreement, and when she opened the velvet tray to log the small valuables before the afternoon exchange he saw her pick up the ring and frown.

“Is this one new?” she asked.

“Drawer B, 12:13,” he said. “Oval stone. Inscription worn.” He did not add: it sits on my finger like a bird that would like to know what your intentions are.

Kim examined it the way a person might a small cunning beetle. “Feels like a grandmother,” she said, and set it down with an involuntary gentleness that he loved her for. “You eat yet?”

“Soon,” he said, because his stomach had been chewing on the thought of the house with the neat hedges all morning, and he wasn’t sure what flavour that thought was—lemon, probably, and also a saltiness you got from tears you refused to acknowledge for a polite period and then allowed.

There were two visitors at the glass he knew without knowing. They had the timbre of people who were used to being helped by structures that had been put up, for their ease, by generations of invisible labour. They were practised nice. One was Annabel, and she had changed her earrings and the shape at her throat, and she had put her hair up in a way that pretended to be indifferent, and the other was a woman he recognised from Mira’s party by the firmness with which she arranged the faces of rooms to express approval. Annabel saw him and blinked through the glass, and her blink was not the blink of someone seeing their reflection. It was directed, and it opened her. You could be irritated with her for a great many things, he thought, not least the casual way she moved from floor to floor in a house of etiquette, but she did not go past people like furniture. He appreciated that in a person who lived among beautiful chairs.

“Patrice,” she said, when the small turnstile let her through and the laws of the station permitted friendliness. “We’re meeting Julian,” she added, apologising in tone for it without actually apologising for it, “but I saw the sign and thought, what a nice thing it would be to be the kind of person who returned something someone else had lost.”

“You could practice,” he said, mildly, and it made her laugh.

“I’ve come to ask a question, and it may be absurd. Did you happen to find a ring? Gold, not too shiny. My grandmother’s sister’s. It does a sort of wobbly thing round one side which is the only way I know it, because anything can be gold and sentimental and ours. It has a scratch on the inside that is almost—but not quite—a letter.”

The air in the glassed room did a small trick. Patrice felt it from the bottom of his ribs to the small finger on his hand. He had anticipated the ring would draw a person the way a smell might draw bees, but he had anticipated an old man with a hat and lost sentences, or a woman who had taken all the buttons off a cardigan one by one to pass the time. He had not anticipated Annabel’s bright surety. He had not anticipated the way Mira would be in the space, instantly, because Annabel meant Mira and all the other things that had come into orbit. He thought briefly of the old gentleman with the coat and the phrase as engineer cunning, It was like a promise someone else kept.

“I can show you what we have,” he said. The phrase was a talisman and a contrivance. He lifted the velvet tray and set it down and did not look at her looking. The ring sat beautiful and plain among the failed circlets and the little lies people wear. Annabel leaned in like a person who did not require invitations, and then stopped her breath. It made a little sound that he will later remember like a bell inside a bell.

“It’s the wobble,” she said, with a laugh that did her kindness credit. “I can’t explain what I’m—oh.” She reached a finger out, not to take, to ask. Patrice nodded and she touched, and then she said, very softly, “Hello, Alice. I haven’t seen you since the garden.”

The other woman with her looked at him and did not try to hide the assessment one bit. “It’s an heirloom,” she said, as though this explained everything.

“That happens,” he said. “The station is good with heirlooms. It is also good with plastic toys missing a limb.”

“And what do you need from us?” Annabel asked. She was not used to failing to identify the rules, and she rendered humility in such a way that it made her more charming than anyone else in the room.

“Proof of ownership,” he said, because he could not let the ring decide for him, however warm it had been, however trustful its gold. “Anything you can tell me that I do not already know from watching your face.”

Annabel looked into the middle distance the way a person looks when they are about to ask their mind to go back in time and fetch a document from a drawer in a house that may not even have the same drawers it had when last you were small. She lifted the ring without lifting it entirely and tilted it and frowned in a way that gave her a vertical line between her eyebrows that would one day be somehow very appealing on a person who had grown comfortable with being an adult. “My grandmother used to keep it in a sugar bowl with a lid that looked like a lemon,” she said, and smiled because she had not known she remembered that. “She said it made the sugar braver. There’s a scratch on the inside where my uncle tried to cut it off a finger when he was ten because he thought he’d married his sister by stealing it. The scratch tries to be an S but gives up. There was another ring, with a ruby, which is somewhere else, because we all stopped keeping things in bowls after the burglary, except my mother who refuses to be redesigned that way.”

Patrice had not known the sugar bowl. He had not known any of the details but the warmth and the initials that might be or might not be. He nodded and Kim nodded too, with her migraine on her face like a bad weather report. They both understood how often people made rich stories to smooth their way into possession, and how often those stories were as true as anything that carried weight in a courtroom. He asked for an address, a name, and the person behind the name who would sign the page that said, yes, this belongs with them, the ring and the family and the sugar and the lemon that had trained an entire generation to take sweetness with acid.

“It’s my mother who will know where the paper is that says the thing we need to say,” Annabel said. “She is in the South Yarra house with the good prison plants. Can I bring you something in exchange, aside from cake? Are you a person who would appreciate a book you could not otherwise afford? I do this, sometimes. People send me books hoping I will make them important with my attention. I have none to spare, but I could at least cause a redistribution event.”

“Two tram passes expired last winter and a lump of blue-tack disguised as a god would be ample,” Patrice said, and made her laugh again because that was an easier exchange than anything involving debt.

“Come Sunday,” she said, impulsive, which was putting a foot on a bridge without asking who had built it. “Bring your friend. I did mean to—it seems ungallant not to include you when you are the most cinematic thing I have encountered today.”

He knew what she meant and did not. He knew the way he had stood with the loudspeaker in his hand and made a sentence that had conjured a person out of the crowd. He knew he was good at returning things. He did not know how to return himself to the right rooms.

“Perhaps,” he said. “I have a conflict with a creek and a book and potentially a lemon.”

“Bring the lemon to the creek,” she said, and when she went she left the space altered in the way fine weather alters it—you notice the lack only later, when it rains.

He told himself now he had an errand. Errands were shapes you could move inside, like jackets. He went home with his body too big for the afternoon and sat in the yard and looked at the balcony and waited for the scrape of the balcony chair. It came without grace and he loved it. Mira leaned over with that look of relief that was not for him and was for him both, and then she propped her chin in her hand and looked at the world as though it had told her a few things and she was deciding which she believed.

“I saw you,” she said. “On the loudspeaker, or rather, I heard you, which is seeing but with more sense. Red scarf. Cross cat. The city told that story to itself. There were three people at the table who said, what a nice thing, and then went back to discussing the percentage by which they believe people are saved by art.”

“Taxes save people,” he said. “But we don’t cook them in late pans and hand them around with drinks.”

“You cook yours in the morning and hand them around through a hole in a window,” she said, with a grin that was exhaustion’s cousin. “You should come Sunday.”

“To the house with the plants that behave,” he said, dry because he had not yet cleaned the dust from the word Sunday and he hoped she would do it for him. “I’m considering it. How was the hallway?”

“I kept thinking I should love it because the corners were the right angle and the light came in at four o’clock like a planned party,” she said. “But the skirting boards had been painted too many times and I worried someone had sealed in a mouse and half a century of decisions. Annabel, though, she makes—what is that word—she makes a tent out of her attention and you can sit under it without getting rained on. I like her, which feels either like good taste or betrayal depending on who you are of an evening.”

“Both,” he said. “Most things are.”

“She asked about you,” Mira said, and then looked away because she had not meant to say it like that, like she didn’t carry him gently and keep him from bumping against the furniture of her other hours. “She said you spoke like a person who has fallen in love with inanimate objects and expects them to behave.”

“They do,” he said. “Up until they don’t. Then they require cake.” He hesitated, and what came out next was either bravery or a tiny mistake with consequences. “Would you walk with me? Not now. Tomorrow. Merri Creek. I can show you the place where the water goes under the street. It makes the sound a person makes when they’re trying not to do the crying yet.”

She looked surprised and then charmed and then one of her edges softened visibly, like bread under steam. “Yes,” she said. “If I do not disappear into a warehouse in Footscray to pretend to know about eaves for a freelance piece someone will forget to pay me for, I will walk and look at a creek. I will bring a pencil we can use to label the noises.”

He let himself smile with the whole of his mouth and did not feel punished by it. “I will bring sandwiches,” he said. “Solid ones. Cream cheese and cucumber pretending to be aristocracy. Maybe one with something rude, like a lot of mustard.”

“That’s the one I’ll take first,” she said. “You know me too well.”

It felt like too much to hold and also like exactly the correct amount, and he was learning that that sensation, too, was a feature of being alive not a bug to report to product.

The next day the station did a different kind of humming, sustained and forward, the way a place does when a footy game is scheduled and the trains are full of men acting as though their elbows are a government. He did the morning with his smile and his ledger and his ring that seemed almost to diminish itself when he was too occupied to pay it mind, as if it had some generosity. At eleven the elderly man with the coat returned, his hat still doing its best impression of being a hat and not a flag of surrender.

“I thought,” the man said, carefully, as though speaking into a wind that could steal words, “I would look again. It is not reasonable to think it would come because I want it, but I wanted to do the wanting anyway.”

“We have something,” Patrice said, and his own carefulness mirrored the man’s. “We have other some things too. But one in particular that has listened to a sugar bowl.”

The man blinked at him, and the blink was a step on the path between strangeness and relief. He looked down at the tray with the rings and he took his time, and when his finger arrived at the gold oval with the cloud he did not pick it up like a prize. He put his fingertips beside it the way you would put two fingers beside the wrist of a friend to check they are still being themselves. “Alice,” he said, and the name did not sound as though the ring belonged to her so much as she belonged to it.

“You’re not A.S.,” Patrice said, and then corrected himself, because letters are foolish little machines that pretend to be an entire person. “Or perhaps you are.”

“Arthur,” the man said, faintly amused by the suddenness of confiding. “Which is old-fashioned in a way that makes shop assistants look pleased with me. Arthur Sand, of the Sands who were once fishers and then sold lamps. But she was Alice. Small in the particular way women were small when the air between the rooms was full of certain kinds of rules.”

“Do you have anything?” Kim asked, appearing beside Patrice like a relief map. “To sign this. To say please and thank you. To fix the ring to you more officially than your heart seems to want to.”

Arthur looked up and he performed an expression that made a person want to bow. He took from his coat a paper the colour of nicotine and the thickness of good decisions. On it a name had been written with a fountain pen with ink that had bled like veins. It was a receipt in a column book for a ring purchased at a shop at the corner of a street that had probably since been renamed. The date was the kind of old that made people at dinner parties say, imagine. The initials, if you squinted, were A.S. but perhaps only because you wanted them to be.

This was what proof looked like and also how modern life refused to recognise proof. Patrice read it anyway and handed it back and said, “Would you like to hold the ring,” and Arthur said, “Not yet,” with such steadiness that it undid something in Patrice he had been pretending was already undone. “Not until I have had a moment before I husband it again. It misbehaved, and it is back, and I need a second to think about what the behaviour means.”

“Would you like to sit,” Kim asked, indicating the chair that was meant for the kind of people who tell stories and wait. Arthur sat, carefully, in a coat that had belonged to someone else if you knew how to look. He looked at Patrice and then at the ring and then anywhere but the ring, because it is hard to look at loved things you’ve lost when they are suddenly behaving like objects again.

“You can leave it here,” Patrice said. “The optimum thing to do in the world is often to leave the thing where it is safe and let your mind catch up. We can give you a ticket that says, I owe myself a reunion.”

Arthur smiled without showing his teeth and took the ticket and this time his fingers, steady like small boats, lifted the ring and he kissed it like manners. “You are an honest man,” he said. “Do you know what a rare thing that is in a place built to hurry?” He slid the ring into the small pocket adults tend to use when the thing is more valuable than money and stood and put his hand flat to the glass. “Do you ever go to garden parties?” he asked, and the question was so odd Patrice laughed in a burst before he could be decorous and then said, “Sometimes, apparently.”

“Good,” Arthur said. “Because you should stand on the grass and make the kind of mistake young people make which is to tell the truth in a room built for polite lies. It will upset absolutely everyone and then someone will tell the story of it later with pride. Forgive me,” he added, as if he had become too much like someone’s grandfather at great speed. “I’m thinking about a lemon tree we had behind a house and how the fruit refused to be sweet until it was cut into cake.”

After Arthur left the day pushed on, but it had a different resilience to it, as if the stations of the city had moved a fraction. At closing, when the low sun turned the glass into a mirror and he saw his own hands as separate from him, he wiped down the little counter and put the ledger away and didn’t quite put the ring back into the tray. He hesitated, which had become a habit with it, and then he set it on his finger and felt the blood there notice its presence the way a creek notices a fallen branch and immediately composes itself around it.

He made the sandwiches at home like a person trying to be good at looking after other people even when he was not sure he had yet earned the job. He put too much mustard on one on purpose. He wrapped everything in waxed paper as if it were 1952 because it felt kinder and because cling-wrap was like lying to time. He put the ring into his pocket for the walk because he wanted to be able to feel it against his leg like a small animal reminding him he still had that choice to make—to be or not be the thing unseen. He wrote on a scrap of paper with a pen that liked to sputter, Merri Creek, ten-ish, bring a pencil if you like, and slid it under Mira’s door with a thrill that made him feel ridiculous and nineteen. On his way back down the path the Greek owner from the terrace kitchen stuck his head out with a towel over his shoulder and the smell of lamb like a sermon.

“Patrice!” he called, great and generous. “You’re thin like you are choosing to be when there’s no good reason. Take this.” He held out a tin with a snap lid that had once held biscuits from Denmark and now held something that smelled like oranges and childhood.

“Koulourakia?” Patrice guessed, trying the word like a friendly dog.

“Paximadia,” the man said, proud and stern, but smiling. “Or something like that. My wife taught me, she says I make them like a person who thinks he is a grandmother. Bring them to wherever you are going that needs sweetness. The city eats better when we feed it ourselves.”

He took the tin with both hands because sometimes you must perform the right respect in order to become the person who knows it by instinct. He went to bed early and the dream he had was a lit corridor with doors slightly ajar and each room being a time he could have taken and did not, and the ring on his finger made the doors slow as if to say, think again.

In the morning the creek obliged them by being a creek. It had gone honest after rain and showed its stones without coyness. The path ran alongside like a sentence you could choose to walk down or leave unfinished. Mira arrived with her hair in a knot that had lost negotiations, a jumper that had admitted more weather than was strictly ideal, and a pencil tucked above her ear like a continued argument. She was carrying a notebook the size of a regret and she looked like sleep had tried but not entirely succeeded.

“Hello,” she said, and when people say hello in that tone what they mean is thank you and also I have saved space for this.

He handed over the mustard and she took it like a dare and grinned with her mouth full and when she had warned her sinuses of what was to come she said, “I feel like a person in a postcard right before they get rained on and then remember they are human.”

“Let’s make a map,” he said, and showed her the place where the creek went under the street and made the caught sound, and she wrote down, throat clearing under bridge, wood note between stones, cyclist bell like positive reinforcement. They sat and were silly with the seriousness that the best silliness requires. They argued for ten minutes over whether ducks had favourite corners of the water like frequent drinkers at a pub. They watched a boy lose a stick and then improvise grief quickly into a project to locate a better stick. They let themselves be brief animals in the sun.

At some point he told her about Arthur’s ring in a way that did not give away that the ring had opinions about where it stayed. He told her about the sugar bowl and the almost-S and the lemon tree you had to slice into sweetness. “Annabel came,” he added, not looking at her while he said it, because he wanted to be fair to the fact of Annabel without straining any threads that didn’t need it.

“She would,” Mira said, not unkindly. “She has the kind of antennae that pick up old silver and a person about to decide. Did you like her better or worse for knowing she has grandmothers?”

“Better,” he said. “Everyone is improved by an elder in a kitchen in a story. Even people who never had them find a way to borrow someone else’s. Also Arthur called me an honest man, which is possibly the best extravagance anyone has ever committed on my behalf.”

She looked at him in that direct way she had when she was aligning a thought to a person. “You are,” she said. “You can’t help it. You should meet my brother. He lies as though telling the truth would kill a person he’s swore to protect. It’s not the worst reason to lie but it’s one of the most exhausting to encounter. He would like you for the opposite reasons.” She tore a piece of bread with an intensity that made little crumbs behave like weather. “We should go Sunday,” she said, after a pause. “To the house. If we go together we can stand in the kitchen and under the art and then make a third place: the landing near the stairs that feels like it belongs to neither.”

“I am secretly fond of landings,” he said. “No one expects you to stay there and yet you do, and the view of rooms from small heights is always surprising.”

“Also people forget to police landings,” she said, lowering her voice in a parody of a whisper, “and you can overhear sentences that change how people think about their own families.”

He looked at the creek and at her and at the ring and at the sky doing its best to be blue despite a determined patch of grey. He did not mind wanting. He minded hiding it less than he had yesterday, which he counted as something good to chalk up. He felt the ring do its warmth and then something else, a pressure that was not unpleasant but directed, as if it had opinions about geography. He followed it with his eyes and found he was looking at the bend in the path where a bottlebrush was doing its blood-red show-off and the path turned to climb. There was a woman there. She had the body language that reads in every language as waiting. Her hands were too still. He did not know her. He did not have to know to recognise the shape of someone about to choose whether or not to leave.

“Give me a moment,” he said, not wanting to become a person who believed his instincts were better than everyone else’s and also not wanting to ignore the feeling that had become companionable. He walked up the path and pretended to be the person he always pretended to be when he was about to do the unpractised good thing: a man in a city just taking his share of the morning. The woman looked at him and then away, and he almost left it. Then she took a breath that had the structure of a swallowed sob and he said, softly, “Do you need the station voice?”

She laughed, at once, a short stutter of amusement at the absurdity that a stranger had correctly named the very particular thing she craved. “How did you—no,” she said. “I need the voice you do when you say the words you owned before you needed them. I used to know how. I have two kids and a mother who says lemon proves God loves the tongue and a partner who can’t tell when I am the kind of tired you fix with sleep and when I am the kind other people cause. I came here so I wouldn’t leave something I need to stay.”

He was out of his depth and he knew it and that was fine; most bodies of water in which you learn to swim behave that way. “Would you like me to stand here,” he said, “and ask you why your face is doing that, or would you like me to go and pretend I did not see and you tell the creek your plan and the creek keeps it.”

She considered him. He tried to look like a person who did not require gratitude or drama. “What I want,” she said carefully, “is to walk into the water up to my calves and then swear at it and then come out and eat something sweet and then go home and act as though I went to look at birds and found the same number that were there yesterday, all alive.”

“You could do that,” he said. “I have sweet in a tin. A man upstairs says they are called something with a lot of vowels. They look like half-moons. He says grandmothers can be men. You can borrow mine. It’s not really mine. That doesn’t matter.” He looked over his shoulder and saw Mira waiting for him like a person who had vouched for him somewhere and was being proved right. “We have extra. You would be granting me a kindness by letting me share food I cannot finish without making myself ill.”

She nodded, wordless in the way of people who have decided to choose a different afternoon. He went back to Mira and she met his eyes with a question that did not require much answer; he lifted the tin and they walked together to the woman and Mira handed her a biscuit and made a small joke about lemon and god which made the woman startle and then smile in that astonished way that happens when the world says, I am aware of your mother and her theology. The woman went to the water and did exactly what she had promised and came back with her calves the colour of better decisions and crumbs on her lips and she said thank you three times and each time it was a different meaning and then she left by the path that goes under the trees that make a noise like breath. The ring cooled on his finger and he wondered briefly whether he was beginning to make things up around its behaviour like a man in love with a weather vane.

They walked back a different way and pointed at little houses that had made do with being small by making themselves deliberate. She told him about a building in Sunshine with a veranda that made her cry because the wood had been walked on by a pair of feet for fifty years and had learned them and then been ripped up by a developer who thought wood had no memory. He told her about a baseball cap that had returned to the station four times because it kept trying on heads and not liking them. They stood on a footbridge and thought about the river below the river that remembered its own names. When they parted at the backyard, she leaned on the railing and did not tilt a lemon at him because there was no lemon which felt symbolically tidy.

“Sunday,” she said. “We will put our ordinary shoes into unreasonable rooms.”

“We will stand on the landing like people who have cottoned onto the trick,” he said. “We will take one cake and leave one complaint.”

He slept that night with the ring on and dreamed for once of nothing much, which was the kindest dream he had had in months. On Sunday he put on the ten-dollar shoes and a shirt that had finally forgiven him for being a man who did not iron as often as shirts claim to require. He put the tin from the Greek kitchen under his arm because an old man had told him to bring sugar to the right rooms. He met Mira at the front of the terrace and she had the pencil and a cake box she pretended had descended by accident into her hands from a kitchen in which all women were blissfully stern, and they walked to the tram like a pair of citizens about to attempt that old art of not letting the city teach them their place too hard or too fast.

South Yarra behaved like itself, which is to say it conducted itself with the calm of a suburb that believes it has an immortal soul and is also on very good terms with several magazines. The house sat behind iron that was an argument, and the garden did, as advertised, look like a prison brochure but in a way the prisoners might have enjoyed, with espaliered fruit trees that had opted for discipline. The door opened before they had found the bell because houses like that have staff, whether or not you can see them, and Annabel was at the end of a corridor that had the kind of runner carpet that says someone either has or believes they have family.

“You came,” she said, and that was the opening of the face again but this time it contained also relief and possession, the benevolent kind you feel when you have successfully called in a favour from the friendly part of the universe. “You look like yourselves. Thank god. There are eight men in the back who look like soups have been invented to apologise for their appetites.”

She took the tin and the cake as though they were Fabergé eggs and led them through. He introduced himself to the corridor like it was a person whose name he had forgotten. He saw the piano in its unused room and the rug that had certainly had to be pretended did not cost a paragraph. He saw a woman with a hair that had declared independence and an air that said she had decided many things in her life that had become the lives of others. “My mother,” Annabel said, and the woman turned and looked and Patrice saw the habit of love and the habit of combat in the same eyes and thought, yes, this is how women wear the years they have run.

“Margaret,” she said, and he was in a first-name situation even if they had not earned it. “Who is this delicious person?”

“Lost Property,” Annabel said, as if she had invented him, and Margaret clapped her hands together in a way that made the air behave. “You keep the city honest,” Margaret said. “I tried to do that once with a newspaper and all I got was an ulcer and a very fine set of glasses. Thank you for the biscuits, you do know exactly what to bring.” Her eye dropped to his hand and the ring glinted, and she did the smallest jerk of a body that has not permitted itself to jerk in public in thirty years. “Oh,” she said, and it was not the oh of surprise. It was the oh of memory coming into a room with mud on its shoes.

“Arthur came,” Patrice said, because he did not know why he was saying many things out loud but this seemed like one of the ones that might matter. “He left with it. And then brought it back. And then left with it again. We are all in rehearsal for permanence.”

“Of course he did,” Margaret said, and laughed like a woman who had sat on a landing in 1979 and listened to two people decide the shape of her life. “He will do that forever. He was born moving things between pockets. You’re coming upstairs,” she added, not unkindly. “Of course you are. We’ve moved the sugar bowl. It’s in the room with the lemon light.”

They went, because stairs are invitations to slightly better air. The landing behaved like a landing and introduced them to a window that made everything outside look like it had been composed by a person with a patient hand. Patrice put his hand on the banister and felt it shine beneath his skin and thought of his grandmother and the coin and the lizard and the way small animals are asked to bear the weight of proof. The ring warmed and he did not pretend not to feel it. He turned his head and saw, in a corner of a room with pale walls and the kind of careless painting wealth affords, a little ceramic bowl with a lid shaped like a lemon that had once been held many times and had then been, perhaps, put away as if the holding was a stain.

“Shall we steal cake,” Mira whispered, because she was a person who recognised ceremony and also its human needs. “And also stand under the art for thirty seconds to satisfy the house.”

“We will do both,” he said, and then, because wanting to be seen had turned into a habit he could cultivate and not punish, he turned to the nearest person he did not know and said, “Do you ever think the cohort of lost things should have their own suburb,” and Margaret said, from just behind him, “We tried once, in Collingwood, but they gentrified between the keys and the umbrellas.”

He laughed and took the cake slice and thought, the landing knows us, and then there was a sound below like the house had decided to remember something and a voice that had not been in his life until now rose up like music, and he looked at the ring again and he had the sudden, strong sensation that the next ten minutes would behave like a chapter he would never stop reading even if he went blind.It was an old man’s voice doing its best impression of youth, which is to say it had learned the grace of not pretending too hard. It said “Meg,” in a way that carried up the stairwell like a smell from a pan, and Margaret’s spine did a thing that speaks all languages. She did not hurry because some recognitions deserve dignity, but she moved as water moves around a stone that was in the stream before the stream knew itself. Patrice and Mira followed because where else would you be when a house elected to bring a chapter to the surface.

Arthur Sand stood just inside the front door with his hat in his hands and the coat that had become part of his silhouette. He was thinner in the generous way of people who have shared themselves out over time. He had a paper bag with a bakery’s logo on it dangling from his wrist as though he had felt impolite arriving without sugar. The room altered around him the way rooms do when the version of the past you miss most walks in carrying his own weather. He looked up at Margaret and at Annabel and then at Patrice with a flicker that did not lay claim but did tidy a ledger somewhere behind the eyes.

“You looked taller over glass,” he said to Patrice, as if this were the only safe place to begin, and then he looked at Margaret properly and said, very quietly, “Meg,” a second time, but with something relieved banking at the edges. He put his hat back on as though to protect himself from the fact that he did not suddenly need one in this room. “I thought better to bring the paper than to mislay it again in a kitchen drawer under soup spoons,” he added to the air, holding up a folded sheet that had a neatness out of step with its years.

“You always think better to bring something,” Margaret said, and smiled in a way that went back beyond any decision either of them had claimed as adulthood. “If it rains in your memory, you arrive with an umbrella in mine. Come in. We have lemon that pretends to be cake. We have an honest man. We have a landing that has been very patient.”

They moved as a small herd does when it senses an opening without needing to be told. The unused piano room made space for them as if everything inside had shifted a degree to make room for new weight. People who had been discussing other definitions of value turned their attention to the definition that had walked in wearing a hat. Annabel put a hand out for Arthur’s paper bag with a fondness that made nonsense of the arguments one could make about class. She would always, Patrice thought, try to put the sugar bowl where people with cold hands could find it.

“This is Arthur,” Annabel said for those who did not have the landing’s education. “He is the person responsible for half the stories I have told at dinners where people pretend not to want stories.” She dipped her head towards Patrice with ceremony. “And this is Patrice, who has put a hand very gently on the thread that runs from Flinders Street to the rest of us.”

Julian had a way of appearing at the centre of a scene as if he never quite believed in the existence of peripheries. He approached with his drink at the right level for greeting and his mouth already shaped around amusement. “We are doing artefacts,” he said. “I adore artefacts. Will there be a diorama? I want little people with sensible shoes moving between paper trees.” He had, as ever, the agreeable malice of someone whose mind is only bored by kindness when it feels like an indictment.

“Be polite, Julian,” Annabel said lightly and not lightly, and he tilted his drink in that way well brought-up people have of making rudeness seem like an accident of cutlery. “Arthur, tell the room why we are blessed with your paper.”

“Blessed is steep,” Arthur said, and then his mouth did the tiny quiver of a boy on a landing about to tell the truth to a kitchen. “I am haunted by objects, as men are when they have outlived all the people who impatiently put things down and asked them to wait. Today I am haunted kindly. This,” he lifted the receipt, “is proof of purchase in the language of men whose children went to school and learned to call it provenance. It says that once a ring was exchanged for money, and that is one kind of story. The other story is that a girl named Alice put it in a bowl shaped like a lemon when she washed the floor, and forgot it, and then did not forget who she belonged to, which was no one, which was everyone, which was the family we were before we learned the habit of holding too tight.”

The room had the sense to be quiet in ways expensive rooms do not always manage. Patrice, beside Mira, felt the ring do its little attentive warmth. He hoped the heat did not translate through the cloth of propriety. He could feel the station voice in his throat like a tool in a pocket, ready, but he kept his mouth closed because the best part of telling is the listening to the bit that arrives you did not practise.

“I misplaced it,” Arthur said. “Not carelessly, or not just carelessly. I was thinking of a house with linoleum and a lemon tree that had no reason to be in that climate, and of a boy who thought that cutting metal might cut a story, and of my sister, who was the kind of small you cannot contain without doing damage, and then I put my hand in an empty pocket and came to the place where things go when they are unsure which story they want. And there, a man kept the story for me without improving it, which is a rarer kindness than you might think. It came to me that honesty is the only fashion I have never regretted wearing.”

“Formalise it then,” Margaret said, with the efficiency of a woman who has been accused of sentiment and knows how to sharpen it into action. “Fill your name into the place where the city requires a hand, and then do the thing we have all pretended to forget how to do, and choose who keeps a ring because that’s what rings are for: choosing in public what you have chosen in private.”

Annabel produced a pen with the drama of a conductor lifting a baton. Arthur signed in a script that had learned under an old schoolmaster to mind its letters. There was a breath in the room like weather shifting before rain. Patrice felt it on his arms and in his small finger. He thought of the old man’s earlier advice about telling the truth in rooms like this, and it came to him that he did not have to manufacture a truth to fit the part. He had one. It was not scandalous. It was ordinary. It would do.

“I wore it,” he said, because he understood that the small sin deserves daylight if it is to become smaller. He did not raise his voice, but the room knew how to carry a confession as a choir carries a line. “On my little finger. Not out of want to keep. Out of want to know. It warmed up like an animal deciding whether it will sit,” he added, because lies are made of omissions and he was trying not to lie. “It made other things warmer too. A camera found its way home quicker. A boy met a cat again via a red scarf. Perhaps that was just the day. Perhaps the day was feeling tired of refusing.”

Julian’s mouth twitched almost into kindness and then chose remark. “Our man of Flinders goes full apostle,” he said. “Next he’ll tell us keys remember which stories they lock and the Yarra’s brown is not a colour but a decision.”

“They do,” Patrice said, and surprised himself with the lack of hesitation. He did not look at Julian to convince him. He looked at the piano no one played and at the lemons painting light onto the bowl and at Margaret’s hands. “Keys and rivers and bowls. They make choices about what they are equal to. So do we.”

Margaret made a low sound of pleased agreement that was almost a hum. “This is the advantage of landings,” she said. “You can see who is trying to be in which room. Arthur, since we are pretending at ceremony, would you like to…?”
