He was becoming someone who could look at a day and decide to be exact for it without making a performance, and the decision put a steadiness in his hands that had lately begun to attract other people’s steadiness like it was a magnet. He put his palm briefly on the burn-mark island in the table and felt, foolishly and then not foolishly, that he was checking the temperature of the room he had managed to build between himself and the rest of the city.

By mid-morning the station was misbehaving, which is to say it was simply being itself under conditions that exposed it. A storm came inland with the briskness of a person invited to a meeting that might finally be about something, and the first heavy drops made a noise on the zinc roof that appealed to any latent sense of drama in every body below. The screens blinked into a sulky uncertainty, and the lights decided to be intermittently honest. Water made its own decisions in corners that preferred paperwork, and people either laughed or did the facial arithmetic that produces impatience. Patrice watched the first rivulet find the precise spot where the concourse sloped and write itself a sentence under a line of gumboots, and he felt, against his skin and without touching it, the ring’s attention, which did not heat so much as hum like a polite engine in a cupboard.

Kim came through the side door with her fringe plastered to her forehead and the look of a woman who refused to let water have the last word. She put a towel around the base of a column the way a person throws their jacket over the shoulders of a friend who insists on standing in weather and said, with the dry humour of a person who had earned it, that the city was having a small cry and they should all allow it. He handed her tea and she took it and put her hand lightly on his wrist as if to tip him into a steadier version of himself. It was the kind of touch that reinforces a job description you thought you had invented alone.

When the drains finally sulked into their proper obedience and a line of people in wet sensible fabrics began to form at the little window with dripping bags and apologies that were unnecessary, he let the loudspeaker have him again. He did not give it charm because charm can backfire in rain; he gave it the temper of a person who has been in a small boat and knows how to take orders and enjoy them. He said there would be delays and that the weather was not a moral failing, and he said that children were not in charge of remembering umbrellas and that anyone who wanted to throw theirs away in a rage could leave it with him and he would find it a home with someone who had made better friends with water. The room breathed and organised itself, and he saw two teenagers take the initiative to collect puddles into one, which is citycraft of the old school.

In between the rushes he had small encounters that replaced the work of a sermon. A woman in a red coat handed him a pair of wet gloves with the deliberate air of someone repaying a debt you did not remember incurring and said, “For the cat,” and he knew her by the curve of gratitude on the edge of her mouth and said yes as if to an old acquaintance. A man in an expensive suit asked him, with total seriousness, whether the rain would cause the river to rise to a point which would endanger his shoes, and Patrice said he hoped so, for the shoes’ education, and the man laughed, which meant the shoes would survive the day. An older couple shared a thermos and told him, as though it was the sort of information that belonged in a ledger, that they had decided to be kind to each other again because the price of oranges had gone down and there was no longer any excuse for stinginess.

Around noon a parcel arrived, damp at the corners, with his name on it in an unfamiliar hand that made the letters behave like they were in a small seminar together. He wiped his hands and opened it with the care you owe anything that has crossed an ocean in order to arrive in your small life, and inside there was a map of Rotterdam with pencil arrows that looked like the tracks of a creature you would want as a pet. A note tucked into the fold explained the arrows in a way that did not explain them at all and said that the bridge names were as good as any names for children and that the stairwells here had developed the habit of smelling like tomato sauce in the late afternoons as if to let the city believe it had one home. There was also, under the map and a curl of tissue paper, a little tin of something that rattled mildly, and when he opened it the smell came out and did something nice to the underpart of his tongue: stroopwafels, contraband, two, wrapped in sacrilegious plastic because even countries with strong ideas have to negotiate with packaging.

He took a bite at the exact wrong moment because a man arrived at the glass with the expression of someone whose solution is in the room and whose pride is trying to keep it out. The sweet glued his teeth together and he gestured with apology, and the man’s mouth did the unwilling curve of a person suddenly on the same level as a stranger. He said he had lost a folder of sheet music somewhere between platform seven and his seat and whether, in the event that it had been eaten by the weather, he was permitted a small grief in public without being told to be brave. Patrice, with his mouth returned to service, said that grief was exactly the correct tone for rain if you didn’t decide to make a joke, and then found the folder under a bench where the tide had delivered it and saw the word “requiem” and didn’t remark on irony. The man took the folder as if taking his own face back and nodded his thanks in a way that made Patrice briefly think he was about to see a person cry into a borrowed reality and decided, quickly, to make a distraction, which is also a civic service.

By late afternoon the storm had receded into a complaint and the station returned to its working hum. The ring sat where it had been, on the velvet, obedient and plain, and he found himself tempted by the superstition of wanting it to take the credit for the fact that nothing very bad had happened in a building that knew how to teach people to escalate. He left it alone in order to respect the boundary he was developing between presence and talisman. He wrote in the ledger in his clear hand the things that had gone and the things that had come back, and in the margin of the day he wrote a line he hoped he would not lose: men with umbrellas become less objectionable when they imagine their umbrellas as someone else’s small roof.

At home that evening the grapevine shook off its bath and the radio returned to itself with a little sigh that could have belonged equally to a machine and an aunt. He took the map to the table and traced the arrows like someone learning to write with the opposite hand. He liked the names because they sounded like decisions and also like the sort of musical phrases you can hum in a kitchen without sentimental damage: Erasmusbrug, Willemsbrug, Brienenoord. He wrote her a reply that wandered like a kind person at a market and told her about the rain here and the way it made everyone tell the truth for one hour and then go back to being efficient, and he put a photograph of the lemon bowl in it that he had taken in the kitchen with Margaret’s permission and three jokes entirely at the expense of Julian because he knew she would need something to laugh at that wasn’t an installation.

Two days later Arthur arrived with a lamp. It was a small thing with a shade that had learned to be modest and a base that knew how to sit on a table without making noise. He held it like an apology for not having brought something less obviously symbolic and then put it down with the ceremony people use when they are returning an animal to a place they think might feed it better. He said he had found it tucked in a cupboard behind a box of odds that had lost their ends and that it had had no reason to bring him to Patrice except that it had done so. Patrice touched the little brass pulley on the cord and felt the object’s relief at being considered a little solemnly by someone whose life did not require it.

“My father,” Arthur said, with the certainty of a man who has lived beyond the time when he thinks names only belong in certain rooms, “sold lamps and then sold the idea of selling lamps and thought that both were equally honest because they made space for other people’s evenings. I cannot walk into a good light without telling on myself. I saw your window and thought: yes, here is where I would have put a lamp if I wanted to see the faces of people realising the thing they lost is not the same as the thing they will be without if they do not get it back.”

“It’s better policy than some brochures,” Patrice said, which he had learned he could now say to people like Arthur without the sentence either sounding as if he were paying himself or insulting the people who wrote brochures. Arthur nodded and then, as if the lamp had reached out via his old man’s professional instinct, asked about the ring, and Patrice told him, without drama, that it was in the tray and had been a good citizen of the little room and had warmed when the room asked for a little more than it had the right to and had cooled when asked to let other objects have their turn. Arthur looked satisfied as if he had made a small but correct change to a document.

That week, in a clumsy, honest way, the station declared itself a venue. Annabel had arranged a small event there under the pretext of a fundraiser for a program that improved signs in languages other than the usually privileged ones, and she had chosen the hour when the concourse knew how to be present without resenting it. There were no champagne flutes because the city would have mocked them; there were paper cups with coffee and the smell of sesame pastries that had the exact right aggression for a public place. Margaret stood where she could see the elegant people restraining themselves and the not-elegant discovering they were invited, and she had that pleased expression she had when the real thing had been accidentally allowed to happen.

Patrice did not speak from a stage because there wasn’t one; he spoke from the little window and the megaphone made a joke of itself and then stopped. He said the city needed to learn to read itself back to the people who had taught it its own letters, and he said signs that change shape for those who need them most were not indulgences but corrections, and he said the loudspeaker had learned a new tone this year and it would be a shame if it forgot. He did not believe he had said anything clever and did not feel the need to pretend he had. He watched a boy translate for his grandmother and enjoyed how the boy held back from explaining the jokes, because that was respect. He watched Julian standing near the pastry box with a face that said he was about to enjoy being outflanked by genuine civic engagement, which undercut the joy in a way that made it better. He watched Kim take a small bow when someone thanked her for keeping the drawers from turning into a pantomime and felt how good it is to be proud of someone else at your place of work.

In the mean-level midnights of the week he wrote her emails that were careful not to be visits she could not afford. He told her about a man who had brought in a butcher’s coat with the front scrubbed thin and a packet of photos of meat arranged like sculpture and how he had said, inexplicably and perfectly, that his grandfather had believed pigs thought in sonnets. He told her about a girl who had brought a poster of a missing dog with glitter on it and looked terrified of the room and how he had given her a pen without a chain and she had stood a little taller because someone had decided she could be trusted, and two days later the dog had been found asleep under a table in a house he had never met. She sent back a list of bridges with notes about the ways their undersides supported small acts of the private life, and the discovery that the Dutch had a formal word for the practice of making a city untrip itself and that the practice felt familiar to her body now that she had a name for it.

Thursday brought an absence that had no bad intention and still managed to try him. He opened the little velvet tray to log the day’s valuables and saw the dent of the ring’s body and no ring. He felt time bend in that useful way that gives you a gift of slow when your first instinct is speed. He did not panic out loud. He panicked internally in a measured way that allowed for inventory. He lifted the felt as if it were a polite animal, he checked the underside of the ledger where objects sometimes tried to marry themselves back to paper, he asked Kim if she had moved anything and she had not, and then he permitted himself a moment of anger which was not directed at any person but at the idea of being made to feel he had been foolish for allowing sentiment near a job.

The security man with the practical gaze came to the counter when Patrice asked and watched the footage with the attention of someone who has trained eyes to notice left-handedness and hats that want to be masks. They saw very little for a long time and then they saw a girl with a school bag that had been loved past retail. She leaned on the counter as if to watch the velvet with the respect that children have for red ropes, and she put two fingers down not because she intended to steal but because she wanted to test whether the circle would behave like a circle and roll, and when it did she followed it with her hand without thinking, the way you do when a thing has already declared its motion. Her face in the footage when she realised what her hand had done made Patrice’s stomach do the controlled fall of a person who has jumped from a height he has calculated exactly and is still surprised by air.

They found her eventually not through police but through the neat method of asking the cleaner if he recognised the badge on the bag and him saying his niece had that cartoon and that hair and that guilt. She came to the window with her bag held like a confession and placed the ring on the counter with the tenderness of someone returning a baby bird. She was thirteen with the drama and restraint that makes such numbers alarming; she was brave in the particular way children are when they think they have been unalterably bad. He did not permit the adult instinct to lean on her with both his open hands. He asked her what had happened and she told him exactly what he had seen but with the emphasis shifted somewhere more interesting: the circle had wanted to complete itself away from a tray, and she had briefly believed she understood something other people did not, and then she had understood only that actions have gravity.

“It belonged to a bowl for a while,” he said, and she looked at him like he was using metaphor as a smoke screen and then decided to play anyway. She asked if things remembered the places that were kind to them and he said yes, if we let them, and she asked if people do, and he said the same thing through a different door. She cried in a dignified manner that he envied and then, surprises upon surprises, asked if she could come on Saturdays sometimes and help put umbrellas in categories because the idea of the categories had made her calm. He said yes with more formality than the choice required and felt something in the room move slightly like furniture being rearranged to admit a new intention. After she left Kim said, in a tone that meant she was allowing hope a seat, that the city had plenty of work for people who felt better in the presence of order.

He sent Mira a letter about that day and she wrote back in a mood that looked like sunlight trying to come sideways through water and told him about a woman at the residency who made models of rooms out of cardboard and then set them on fire to see what parts of a life resisted heat. The woman had been kind to her and also annoying in the way that all people who can afford to burn things are annoying without meaning to be, and Mira had smiled almost more than she meant when the woman had asked if she had someone at home who talked about her in the second person in letters. He considered his answer longer than the question required and then told her the truth in two sentences softened with one small joke because he had learned to portion honesty the way you portion mustard.

At the beginning of week three, the Lady of Tracing came with the softness of victory in her mouth. She had found the man whose letters were stamped with a hotel logo and the bottom of a lowercase g that had run like a river, and he lived in a room with a curtain that tried but failed to be a wall and a kindness in his eyes that did not suit the neighbourhood the rent had chosen for him. He came to the window in a shirt that had owned better days and put his hand on the shoe-box as if it could jump, and when he asked if he was allowed to open one in front of them Patrice said yes, please, like a family member who had learned not to suffocate moments with ceremony. The man pulled a letter as though it might be a live fish and read three lines and then, in a tone that would haunt and bless Patrice for a long time, he said, “I didn’t imagine you right,” and then, “I did,” and then he folded the paper back into its envelope as the day made room for several pasts and refused to collapse anything to make it easier.

Time being time, and cities being cities, and people being people, interruptions kept doing their good job of preventing anyone’s life from being a set piece. Annabel asked him to meet her on a street that liked to sell modern chairs in order to vet the chair he was meant to be when she took him to a second, more elaborate panel about public feeling and who gets it in doses they can survive. He did not mind being auditioned; he liked the seriousness of it and the way she made serious look like a garment you could wear without sweating. They argued for ten minutes about whether part-time ferocity was an asset, and then she told him in the careful tone of a person trying to be friend and not rescuer that she had seen Margaret sit down in a way that did not suit the word sit and that she was closely fine and also beginning to be the kind of human whose days require coordination.

He went by the house with the prison garden that afternoon under the pretext of picking up a book and left with a small commission that meant more to him than he let himself consider. Margaret asked him to keep an eye on a box of photographs that had developed a bad habit of helping themselves to the floor. He put them back in their container with a stern tenderness and saw, in the second one down, a picture of a kitchen table with a burn so exactly placed it made him feel briefly that houses sometimes call each other up at night and compare notes. Margaret watched him and did not make the obvious remark; she asked instead if he would do her the favour of standing where the room could see him when the younger people came by to explain their opinions about public art and she was too tired to tenderise them herself. He agreed because there was no universe in which he would not, and she did him the honour of pretending she had given him a job and not a blessing.

On Thursday, after two days of weather with the personality of a patient dog, the alarm in the station went off not because of smoke or crime but because a man with a sense of theatre had decided to propose to a person he loved using the loudspeaker and had triggered something he had not intended. The sound was too much; the room startled and then bristled; his shoulders did the thing they did when fields turn in a wind. He picked up the megaphone and spoke right into the alarm as if speaking into panic itself, and told the room to lend its small bravery and wait forty seconds, which is a long time and not long at all, and then he put the megaphone down and let the alarm argue with their breathing. When it stopped, the room applauded itself in the polite way that civic organisms do when they have proved they are not entirely feral, and then someone brought the man with theatre a bouquet that had not been bought for him but which the station had decided to reassign to his afternoon. The proposal, admirably, did not involve the loudspeaker. It involved a language that had been a habit between two people for long enough to make a promise. He liked how much of the day was not about him and wrote two lines in the ledger at the bottom where calls and announcements do not belong: alarm stopped, yes heard.

In the evening, with the rain returned to the window in its thriftier form and the grapevine making a shape of forgiveness against the sky, he took the lamp Arthur had brought and set it on the little table by the wall where the radio lived. He did not turn it on immediately because turning it on immediately would have been admitting he needed it, and he tried to be the kind of person who made things feel invited instead of requisitioned. The room seemed to approve of its new furniture. He thought of his father with his neat ruler and his generous failure and felt, without sentimentality and with respect, the way that leaving quietly had bent a boy’s spine into a shape that made him stand better now. He wrote to Mira about alarms and chairs and mothers who had decided to sit differently and about the boy with his map and his friend with his performance of boredom and told her that the city had decided to lend them its punctuation for a while and they owed it back with interest when she returned.

On a Sunday afternoon that had considered being hot and then thought better of it, he took a walk that he did not call a pilgrimage to the bridge where the creek went under the street and the bottlebrush made its red like a promise. He carried the ring in his pocket because he did not entirely trust himself to leave it in the drawer when the day had the feel of an argument he did not want to start. He thought, as he often did when he walked, in the tone of someone narrating a documentary about animal behaviour in suburban corridors. He thought about what it meant to look after something that might be magic if you were unhelpful enough to use that word, and what it meant to use it in a way that did not turn your life into a story about you. He thought of a kitchen in Rotterdam where a pencil lay on a table with a clock that lied happily in the morning and how wanting was not a kind of theft if the person you wanted had asked you to hold a piece of their ordinary in your palm.

There was a boy on the bridge with a fishing rod. He was fishing for nothing you could eat in good conscience and did not look embarrassed to be doing it, which Patrice admired. The boy had the face of someone who had been told to wait long enough that the discipline of it had turned into personality. He had a sandwich in a bag that had been folded twice, lovingly, and a thermos the kind of old that tries to pretend it is new out of pride. He glanced up and then, because he was young and therefore didn’t know the rules that prevent joy from sharing itself spontaneously, he said, “Sometimes you don’t catch a thing and it’s still worth the doing,” and Patrice said yes in the voice of a person who had decided that this was an important part of his job too.

He took the ring out and held it like a coin he intended to set down at a counter and be given something adequate in return. He put it back in his pocket, because sometimes the right ceremony is not to perform a ceremony at all. He walked home through streets that had practiced being themselves this week and felt, again, the lightest version of courage, which is the kind that lets you expect very little from a day and still go to it with an appetite. In the yard he could hear the Greek upstairs singing to a pot. The song had no words and all of them, and it made the grapevine behave better than the trellis could ever manage.

When the postcard came showing a sky full of gulls trying to decide whether to belong to water or roofs, he looked at the stamp and thought how many hands conspire to let you hold a bird with ink on your own fingers. She had written about a woman on a ferry who had taught her to stand with her knees loose so the river couldn’t win, and how having the right bend in your legs is the whole trick and no trick at all. He wrote back that he had learned to bend in the same place for different reasons and that the city had introduced him, this week, to a dog that knew how to sleep under the name of patience. He drew a small map of the stairwell where the light made a shape she liked and wrote under it, lightly: return here, which he knew was an instruction that did not tell her anything she did not already know and still felt permissible.

The week turned again, and this time he could feel the edge of the turn. Not a crisis; he was learning the city did not often do him the favour of telling him when the big things had begun until afterwards. It was the small adjustment in appetite that a building gets when one of its occupants starts to pack, and the way a drawer begins to remember what it is to be emptied and filled in a different rhythm. He kept the ring near because he had found that it behaved well under supervision and because, if he was honest and he was becoming, he enjoyed being the person who had to make the ordinary decision about where a circle should sit at the end of each day. He put his hand on the ledger and considered writing the word forward under a date, but found he did not need to perform that sentence to know he was doing it. The bell from a tram came in, late and cheerful, and for once he let it choose his mind for him. He agreed to the day and the way it would remember him when he looked back, and then he put the ring in its tray and the megaphone on its hook and stood up straight because sometimes that is the only spell that works.
